response:
[start of motion plan]
The task is to give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck.

Mapping World Motion to Wrist Motion:
The provided workspace image confirms the robot end-effector is positioned near the man's neck, grasping it gently. The environment includes a workbench surface below and various objects around, but the neck is free to move slightly with massage motions. The neck is soft tissue covered by skin, flexible but limited by anatomical constraints. The robot-controller can apply moderate forces and torques with position and torque control, and has 6D motion capability with tactile feedback. The man is seated with head lowered, providing clear access to the neck region.

The labeled wrist axes correspond to the world as such: The red axis (X-axis) points roughly to the man's right side (rightward motion in the world corresponds to rightward in the image). The green axis (Y-axis) points roughly forward into the workspace (forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the image). The blue axis (Z-axis) points roughly upward in the camera frame (upward in world corresponds to upward in image). The wrist frame is oriented so that the grasping point on the man's neck aligns with these axes accordingly.

The blue axis represents wrist Z-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to upward and downward motions relative to the man's neck—lifting the grasp or applying pressure by pushing downward or lifting upward. Positive Z is upward lifting motion, negative Z is downward pressing motion.

Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Z-axis, the object must move cyclically with downward and upward motion to simulate massage pressure and release along the neck.

The red axis represents wrist X-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to lateral side-to-side motions relative to the neck—massaging across the neck horizontally. Positive X is motion to the man's right, negative X to the left.

Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist X-axis, the object (neck tissue under grasp) must move gently side-to-side to simulate side-pressing and kneading massage actions.

The green axis represents wrist Y-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to forward and backward relative to the man's body—sliding motions along the length of the neck. Positive Y is motion forward into the body, negative Y is pulling motion away from the body.

Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Y-axis, the object must move gently in a longitudinal sliding manner up and down the neck (forward and backward) to complete the massage.

To accomplish the task in the wrist frame, the object must be moved with combined cyclic motions in Z for pressure, X for side kneading, and Y for sliding along the neck, with forces applied carefully to avoid discomfort or injury.

Understanding Robot-Applied Forces and Torques to Move Object in the Wrist Frame:
To estimate the forces and torques required to accomplish give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck, we must consider the following:

- Object Properties: The neck is soft tissue with low to moderate compliance, consisting of muscles and skin. The mass under the grasped area is small, roughly estimated at under 1 kg for local tissue mass. Friction between the robot end-effector's surface (likely plastic or rubber) and skin is moderate, with a static friction coefficient estimated at ~0.5.

- Environmental Factors: Gravity acts downward on the tissue and end-effector (around 9.81 m/s² downward). The neck tissue offers some resistance to deformation and sliding but is pliable. There is no rigid hinge; motion involves soft tissue deformation. Surrounding environment supports the rest of the man's body.

- The relevant object is the portion of the man's neck tissue grasped by the robot end-effector. Estimated mass is approximately 0.8 kg. The contact between gripper and skin has a static friction coefficient of about 0.5, allowing a firm but gentle grip without slipping.

- The surface of interaction is the skin on the man's neck, which would have a friction coefficient around 0.5 with the robot’s gripper material. The skin is compliant and may deform slightly under applied pressure.

- Contact Types: The robot employs a pinch grasp to softly but securely hold the neck without discomfort. Surface contact is maintained throughout, needing to apply consistent normal forces to prevent slippage.

- Motion Type: The robot performs combined sliding and pressure motions – pushing downward (negative Z) to apply massage pressure, sliding longitudinally (Y axis) up and down the neck, and side-to-side sliding (X axis) to simulate kneading. Gentle rotational motions may be applied to rotate through the muscle fibers (some torque about Z or X axes).

- Contact Considerations: Forces along all three linear axes (X, Y, Z) are required both to move the tissue and maintain contact against gravity and reaction of tissue deformation. Some small torques to apply rotational kneading or gentle twisting may be applied, mainly about Z and X axes.

- Motion along axes: The robot exerts a combination of linear and angular force/torques involving linear motions along x (side), y (longitudinal), z (pressure) axes and angular motions primarily about x and z axes for kneading.

- Task duration: A thorough neck massage cycle performed by the robot will take roughly 30 to 60 seconds at moderate motion speed and force application, to safely provide a gentle, effective massage.

Physical Model (if applicable):
- Relevant quantities and estimates: Local tissue mass under grasp ~0.8 kg. Gravity force = mass × g = 0.8 kg × 9.81 m/s² ≈ 7.85 N downward.

- Relevant equations: Force to overcome static friction F_friction = μ_s × Normal force. Normal force includes holding force plus any force to resist slip due to gravity and massage motion.

- Relevant assumptions: The skin tissue compliance allows small displacements without pain; the robot applies forces within safe limits (~5 N maximum contact force per axis). Friction coefficient ~0.5.

- Computations: To hold tissue against gravity, 7.85 N downward force must be supported. To slide/massage gently, forces of up to ~3 N in each direction may be applied dynamically. Grasp must resist slip force ≈ friction × normal force.

- Force/torque motion computations with object of mass 0.8 kg and static friction coefficient of 0.5 along the surface: 
Holding normal force ≥ force needed to counteract gravity / friction ≈ 7.85 N / 0.5 ≈ 15.7 N. Adding margin for manipulation motions, a grasping force between 15 and 20 N is appropriate.

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis: To complete the task and based upon tissue compliance and massage motions, the object in the image must exert positive and negative force cyclically with magnitude about 3 N in X (side to side kneading).

Linear Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon longitudinal sliding massage motion, the object must exert positive and negative force cyclically around 3 N in Y (forward/back sliding).

Linear Z-axis: To complete the task with pressure application (downward massage), the object must exert negative (downward) and positive (upward release) force cyclically with magnitude about 5 N in Z.

Angular X-axis: To provide gentle rotational kneading motions about lateral axis, a small angular torque is required. Estimated torque ≈ 0.3 N-m counterclockwise.

Angular Y-axis: No significant torque required about Y-axis as principal rotations occur about X and Z axes. Thus no angular torque about Y.

Angular Z-axis: To simulate muscle kneading twist motions, a small angular torque about Z-axis may be applied. Estimated torque ≈ 0.2 N-m clockwise.

Grasping force: Given friction coefficient 0.5 and object mass 0.8 kg with applied forces up to about 5 N, the grasping force must be in the range of 15 to 20 N to maintain a safe and slip-free grip.

Python Code with Final Motion Plan:
```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "The object is human neck soft tissue with approximate mass 0.8 kg, low stiffness, skin surface with friction coefficient ~0.5 against robot gripper material."

# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "Cyclic combined motion: gentle side-to-side sliding in X, longitudinal sliding in Y, and pressure application (down and up) along Z with small rotational kneading torques about X and Z axes."

# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of motion across the wrist axes [x, y ,z]. 
wrist_motion_vector = [0.01, 0.015, 0.02]  # small displacement amplitudes in meters, representing typical massage motions

# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [3.0, 3.0, 5.0, 0.3, 0.0, -0.2]  # forces in Newtons, torques in N-m (clockwise negative)

# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 18.0  # Newtons, to ensure firm, slip-resistant grip

# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 45.0  # seconds, typical massage cycle duration
```
[end of motion plan]

The task is to give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck.

The robot is controlled using position and torque-based control, with access to contact feedback and 6D motion capabilities. 
Motions can include grasping, lifting, pushing, tapping, sliding, rotating, or any interaction with objects or surfaces.
Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

Reason about the provided and implicit information in the images and task description to generate a structured plan for the robot's motion. Think about:
- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.
Use physical reasoning to complete the following plan in a structured format. Carefully map the required motion in the world to the required motion, forces, and torques at the wrist.

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
2. Use best physical reasoning based on known robot/environmental capabilities. Remember that the robot may have to exert forces in additional axes compared to the motion direction axes in order to maintain contacts between the object, robot, and environment.
3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."
4. Keep the explanation concise but physically grounded. Prioritize interpretability and reproducibility.
5. Use common sense where exact properties are ambiguous, and explain assumptions.
6. Do not include any sections outside the start/end blocks or add non-specified bullet points.
7. Make sure to provide the final python code for each requested force in a code block. Remember to fully replace the placeholder text with the actual values!
8. Do not abbreviate the prompt when generating the response. Fully reproduce the template, but filled in with your reasoning.
9. Make sure to refer to the provided correspondence in the direction guide between motion in the world frame and positive/negative motion in the respective axes.
